post_body: One and half days to sort out the 'too much oil in the carb' issue just after he had boasted that he'd been doing this for thirty something years   I can truly say that I was awestruck

Hi

The e type was the first car designed using a wind tunnel??

I think not, Bristol Cars used Bristol Aeroplane's wind tunnel in the design stages of the 401 introduced in 1948._________________Bristols should always come in pairs.

Straight 6

V8 V10

I'm not sure I heard it right but I'm sure they said Jaguar invented IRS as drivers were finding it difficult to handle the car as it was so long?.

The restoration was a bodge and looked like it was done in twenty one days.

post_body:
Watched it last night ~ twas awful.... 


Bernie should have stuck to Banglar Bangers

I thought exactly the same, so watched on line   it was dire, the director clearly unsure who his intended audience was.


What was annoying is that they really didn't show any restoration, the engine work was glossed over with the statement that "a piston was fixed" , the body was taken back to bare metal (not a normal bodgers technique) but we didn't see  how they tackled any of the body faults that must have been present in a 50 year old car   ok there was some tapping down of "high's" on the bonnet; staged for the camera, and we saw the filler applied, but was it an inch thick or just a few thou?. I suspect it was the latter as the body blokes turned out what (on the TV) looked pretty good; nice paint equal panel gaps, but the implication was that the body was "full of filler"


Why they made a program that went out of its way to seem to promote bodging; not spent 5 quid on some metal and an hours labour on getting rid of the sunroof, why imply they were fitting secondhand, brake discs, exhaust components and shock's, why stage the phoney crash and make a big deal of surplus oil in the carbs, when they could have at least explained the original misfire...


I think it should have been called "Carry on Restoration" then at least we could have laughed at it!


Dave
quote: Well, I couldn't resist it. After everyone's comments I had to go on line and watch it..

post_body:
I watched it last night, on a "so bad it's good" basis. Yes, the "fixed a worn piston" bit was interesting, just mentioned in passing, in fact I wonder if it was a brake piston and they just didn't mention that to make it sound more complicated. I also thought it might be a bit hard to have painted the inside of the bonnet red without removing either it or the engine, but I don't know E-types that well. I guess there's a chance the PO had done that, as it looked like he had started painting red around it.


Would you use an angle grinder with a grinding disc to remove paint on an E-type? I wouldn't. No wonder they roughed the surface of the metal up so much.


The crash bit was pathetic. An otherwise empty section of garage, strangely-voiced bloke (Alfa Romero? What's an Alfa Romero?) backs slowly into an engine that has no business being there, and it sticks a big dent in the lower quarter panel? No chance. Hard to see why it was much more than a small scrape in real life.


I have trouble believing that second-hand brake disc was going anywhere near the E-type, and I was quite surprised we got as far as the first ad break and they still hadn't bought the car. Would even have been better if they'd stop assuming we have the memories of a goldfish and keep re-showing bits of the program we only watched ten minutes ago![/b]

I agree with all that has been said, really unsatisfying programme.


I noted the car started off with California style bonnet mounted lights that had disappeared in the finished views. 


No mention if the vehicle had been through a SVA following re-import.


The valuer did not appear to peruse any documents prior to putting a value on it. What was the value? Retail, Auction?? 


4 weeks, 7 mechanics, Tweedle Dee & Tweedle Dum and they only made £10,000, not much of a business plan?


Best get it back to California before it rusts and the P38 falls off like fish scales.

I think its worse than that; Cost of mechanics can't be any less than £200 per day, I think there were 4  of them?  for 4 weeks= £200*4*20(days)= £16,000. Cost of car £12,000, leaving £2k for all the parts, trim, paint, overheads etc...... I have assumed the 2 clowns were free 


Dave
quote: 4 weeks, 7 mechanics, Tweedle Dee & Tweedle Dum and they only made £10,000, not much of a business plan?.

post_body:
When this thread started I thought the car in question was a Citroen C5    and I thought to myself "that's not much of a classic". Then I saw it was on last night and everything fell into place. Truly awful!! I don't think a 'properly' restored American spec. E-type 2+2 would fetch £30K. You do all realise that you could win this car?


Art

They should have featured the car I have just worked on...A Rover P5B Coupe.

It had been off the road for many years.

It ran but the brakes were siezed and the bodywork corroded in all the P5`s vunerable area`s.

I had it in the workshop for 15 day`s, I carried out the work and was assisted for 5 day`s by a mechanic friend .

Work carried out ...

New inner,middle and outer sills+ jacking points.

New a posts.

Front wings removed and inner wings repaired.

New front wing bottom repair sections fitted.

New D post`s inner and outer +associated metalwork repairs.

Rear boot repairs to wheelarches and battery box area.

New battery box.

New rear valance and local repairs.

Rear doors repaired.

Area`s next to front windscreen repaired.

Other frabrication repairs as required.

The bodyshell is now as solid as a rock.


My mechanic friend serviced the engine,gearbox,rear axle and changed all fluids.

The braking system was completly renewed.

Bottom ball joints replced (not a straight forward fix).


I took it for it`s mot today and it passed first time.


We carried out the work without any drama or theatrical scenes.


Another Rover P5B saved from the banger boy`s.


                                  Gresham Flyer

Yes but can you:


Find a mate with a lorry load of spares that he will sell for £5


Have a rouge engine lying around  that will be invisible until you hit it.


Refurbish an engine for the cost of "repairing a piston"


Put a new sunroof in the P5 


Spray the car in a different colour


Spend 2 days looking at an exhaust for excess of carb damper oil


Otherwise it just wont interest us :        


Dave
quote: They should have featured the car I have just worked on...A Rover P5B Coupe.

The amount and content of the posts here are mirrored on the lotus forum I am often found on. 


Two points I would raise.

2, Has anyone been onto a Jag forum to see what they think!!!

Buddsy_________________Im looking for an Elan plus 2 for my next resto project...if you see one think of me please!!

OK I've just watched it. Only got halfway through last weeks, but this time I gritted my teeth and used the mute button liberally when the foul-mouthed cockney porker started shouting. I have now found what a distributor does, and cleaning the carbon off is all you have to do to fully service a Porsche engine.

The commercial breaks were a blessed relief, and at least, now, I can't be accused of criticising something I haven't watched all the way through.


I shall not be watching it again. Er, is the porker related in any way to Greg Wallace?_________________If you tie a piece of buttered toast to a cat's back, then drop it off a high building. It will hover just above the ground rotating slowly.

i liked the way he scraped the rotor arm with a something metal .i got my knuckles rapped when i worked in a garage by an old guy for doing the same thing .he said you dont rub anything metal on a rotor arm you use the sidewall of a tyre or something rubber as it takes metal off the rotor arm & alters the air gap in the distributer cap, dont f***in  do it again or youll get another he said,that was twenty odd years ago and i still use the side of a tyre to this day .

They couldn't stretch to a NEW cap and rotor?

probably the same reason they didn't change the oil.....


I certainly don't want to win it anyhow

I don't understand why they left that cheapo front bumper/spoiler thing on it, when they could have probably bought a proper one from the spares place. The colour was awful (compared to the original).


Too much shouty-shouty for me, why couldn't it have been presented more like Grand Designs, rather than something off a children's channel?


R_________________Rick (OCC Admin)

Various 1920s-1960s - Austin, Morris, Commer, Dodge etc.
The previous week's programme was utter rubbish, why watch more of it? I didn't.

Well, I learned a few things. Apparently Scimitars and Land Rovers are rubbish, and Morris Minors are rare. And 1977 911s have an ECU, and as long as there isn't any welding in a specific part of the bodywork (assessed by feel rather than, I don't know, perhaps actually looking at it) it cannot possibly be a cut and shut.


And all through the cut-and-shut section, the "holier than thou" attitude about how if it is, we'll have to scrap it straight away, made me laugh. If you had to imagine the kind of people that might sell a cut-and-shut, and the kind of premises they might work from, well, I don't need to spell it out, do I?


I didn't think program was as bad as the first, some of the historic footage was quite good if a little brief and speeded up. Perhaps we should have a whip-round for a new catch for that workshop door that they take it in turns to slam, but doesn't close properly so it doesn't make a bang.

Didn't watch it ....... I used to have a 911 of that era, they use a Capacitive Discharge ignition system, this requires all HT components to be in tip top condition otherwise misfires are common, HT leads, cap & rotor arm would be changed at least every 2 years, they weren't  expensive... cleaning the cap up is akin to putting tyre paint on a nearly bald tyre  


Dave
quote:
They couldn't stretch to a NEW cap and rotor?

probably the same reason they didn't change the oil.....


I certainly don't want to win it anyhow

post_body:
I think the best of all these programmes either produced in the UK or in the USA was "OVERHAULIN".

Chip Foose is a prolific car builder in his own right and a likable guy.

The presenters Chris Jacobs and Courtney Hansen (later replaced by CJ) were very good as well.


They added a bit of comedy into the format and who could not shed a tear when the car was exposed to the owner and all that american hugging went on (and that was just the guys).

Even the rough tough car builders would all get emotional when hearing how pappa`s Chevy was now a memorial to his death.


Ok about 60 people were involved in the rebuild of these vehicles each time but they did it for real and the finished job was spot on...I would love to own one of these vehicles they must be priceless.


I understand the programme is returning this week 2nd Oct.


I also like watching Chasing Classic Cars with Wayne Carini,a really enthusiastic sort of guy when it came to old automobiles. My name is Wayne Carini and I like chasing cars (as long as its not women said Mrs Carini) at least there is no spanner throwing and trantrums like some other programmes.


As for Salvage Squad I liked Claire Barrett who went on to restore a watermill with her husband in real life,she was the sort of girl who liked to get DIRTY.!!!!


                                          Gresham Flyer

Ah! But is this also the case with the 1977 3.3 fitted with an ECU? _________________If you tie a piece of buttered toast to a cat's back, then drop it off a high building. It will hover just above the ground rotating slowly.
quote: I see that Bernie does not know the correct firing order, 1-5-3-6-2-4 is a typical straight-six but the Porsche flat six 3.3L is 1-6-2-4-3-5.

post_body: Ooh, I withdraw my comments about ECUs. Looking at the original build thread: http://www.myporsche911.co.uk/upb/viewtopic.php?id=14&t_id=25&page=1 it seems it had a 3.2 transplant which has some kind of engine management system. Then it got painted with aerosols, which might be a clue about the blemishes on the roof.

It would have had a 2.7l engine originally with the Boch K-tronic (electro-mechanical) fuel injection, the later 3.0l had the k-tronic until about 82/3 when the 3.2l engine was introduced,that I believe had an ECU.


I thought the program was marginally better than the previous week, would have been better if the staged arguments had been cut, and the time spent on the repairs! at least this show did illustrate some techniques like the guide coat for picking up minor body defects.


What I thought was interesting was the type of adverts during the breaks (assuming the online version has the same as the TV) which were for women s cloths, chocolate bars and breakfast cereal; not the sort of adverts one would expect for the average restorer ?  possibly this gives a clue to the target audience?


Dave

post_body:
The Jag' programme infiltrated our shores this week, courtesy of the Discovery Channel,  AKA  as "Discover the bad acting Channel"


So I watched it and then penned this to them.


Hello


I heard about this programme from my fellow vehicle restorers in the

 UK.    It is nothing more than a fictitious piece of twaddle.


Fake arguments,  "staged"  accident,  and an even worse staged engine

 fault that produced exhaust smoke.


Is  the discovery channel  producing a documentary  or a mediocre drama series ?


There were statements on the show that are 100% inaccurate, but they

 are so inaccurate that they had to be scripted because there are

 supposedly skilled tradespeople working on this vehicle  who would

 never utter such garbage.


Try a little internet research of the show because this poor quality

 production is not bringing your business any good reviews.


No more to add.   I won't watch another_________________Peter L.   --   Formerly "peterwpg" .

Although staged like the rest of the programme, I find the opening 10 minutes or so, where the project cars are "discovered", to be moderately interesting. The rest I watch - sorry Riley541 - for amusement value only.


RJ_________________Rick (OCC Admin)

Various 1920s-1960s - Austin, Morris, Commer, Dodge etc.

Dave

I saw bits of it - I was trying to clear some space off my recorder by watching stuff, so I was switching between this and "No country for old men", which is a reasonable film but a rubbish ending. 


The usual rubbish - they go to see a car that's clearly a breaker, offer £1000 when the bloke is asking £2000, then have to go elsewhere to get a different one. Then come back later and give £250 for just the front seats. Then in the "history" bits where they tell us all about the car, it's illustrated with loads of film clips ... of 968s and 944s along with 928s.

I hope you guys on here that are restoring Fiat 500s watched last night's programme and are now reflecting on whether you should re-do any of your work to match Mawio and teams efforts.  


(I didn't watch the show, managed to resist it completely this week).
I know filler heats up as it sets and judging by the amounts they use I wonder if we've now found the reason for global warming._________________Selling   imperial hand tools for old machinery.

Complete numpties.  It took a whole workshop of them to put the seat-sliders on the rails; I don't even think that was one of their fake items of jeopardy., they had just bent them with their extremely coarse handling.

I suspect that their car could probably now do with a restoration.


On second thoughts, a bit harsh, it had a nice interior and someone is going to get a few years out of it before it starts playing up.

post_body:
I watched a bit of the Porsche one to see if it was as bad as the last series and shan't watch again. pure - but terrible - attempt at comedy. There was quite a scandal when the same chap put a few of the cars from the last series on Ebay I remember.


On a brighter note I came across a series called "Restoration Garage" on National Geographic and it is very interesting. I mean, they take more than two weeks to restore a car, they over-run on costs, their estimates for restoration are realistic as are their time schedules but they are very interesting people and are building a Bugatti Aerolithe from just photos - and in magnesium just like the original. I have recorded the series.

It was indeed appalling TV but what gets me the most is that the makers of such programs think that we would enjoy it  

Do they really think we are stupid enough to believe their rows and trumped up problems, with the same format every week!

2000 quid on a top end engine build and they don't put a new clutch in..


Its a disgrace to call it classic car anything, let alone rescue._________________www.OldFrenchCars.com


We do these things not to escape life but to prevent life escaping us

Terrible or not, just about every car forum has a thread running about it  which guarantees additional viewers; either those who can't believe it'll be as bad a second time or those who can't believe it's as bad as others made it out to be._________________David

quote: Terrible or not, just about every car forum has a thread running about it  which guarantees additional viewers; either those who can't believe it'll be as bad a second time or those who can't believe it's as bad as others made it out to be.

post_body:
The Fiat episode was crushingly dire, the "arguments" stretch credibility to well beyond breaking point. I don't know why I watch it really, I guess the subject still interests me even if the programme itself wants putting out of its (our) misery 


RJ_________________Rick (OCC Admin)

Various 1920s-1960s - Austin, Morris, Commer, Dodge etc.
I might watch it again, but with the volume well and truly muted!!

Yeah ok the format is the same week after week, with the fake arguments etc... But the fact that some people watched it from start to end in this thread, sort of counter balances the negatives. 


I will continue to watch it and filter out what is rubbish but I still prefer to have some "restoration" programs on TV than none.


As far as I am concerned any old car that is restored is a job well done.

It's just another so-called entertainment programme designed to appeal to the kind of people that enjoy the drama without worrying too much about the accuracy. I'd imagine it's aimed at the same people that watch "Storage Hunters" or is it "Ultimate Makeover" where they knock someones house down and rebuild it. I would imagine anyone who has some actual knowledge of any of the subjects covered by these things will be similarly outraged - property developers, antiques dealers, specialist transport companies.


They're OK for what they are, there's always a cliff-hanger for the ad breaks to give the viewer time to get another can of cheap lager and get rid of the remnants of the last one. Something has to fill the schedules now we've got so many TV channels.

I watched the MGB episode, that was enough for me I'm afraid! However, I do enjoy watching Wheeler Dealers when they tackle classics, and that new one with Fuzz Townsend from Practical Classics in it._________________1935 Standard Twelve

1953 Austin A40 Somerset

1958 Austin A55 Cambridge

1959 Austin A35

1987 Austin Maestro 1.3 L

Give the yanks their  do...they make some good shows with some laughs along the way, but quality vehicles at the end.

I noticed on the program tonight that they put a disclaimer at the start. "This program contains rows, rust and wrecks. The garage team are mechanical experts and the car rescued is genuine, although some of what you'll see has been engineered for entertainment."


Well at least the producers have been listening to people who have clearly complained. I would like to differ with the usage of the word expert though. But hey I still watched it.

Well that's another series put to bed mercifully, I had to put it on mute for a while during one outburst in the 'shop during this evening's Corvette build. I don't know why I watched it really, possibly it was in the hope that maybe one episode would be a good use of 60 minutes.

post_body: One and half days to sort out the 'too much oil in the carb' issue just after he had boasted that he'd been doing this for thirty something years   I can truly say that I was awestruck

Hi

The e type was the first car designed using a wind tunnel??

I think not, Bristol Cars used Bristol Aeroplane's wind tunnel in the design stages of the 401 introduced in 1948._________________Bristols should always come in pairs.

Straight 6

V8 V10
I turned off before it was half way through, about where he pulled some supposedly E type parts of the back of a pick up truck.

and as far back as 1934 Chrysler used the wind tunnel for their "Airflow" series.
